title.value: RELIABILITY OF CKA AS A SIMILARITY MEASURE IN DEEP LEARNING
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: RELIABILITY OF CKA AS A SIMILARITY MEASURE IN DEEP LEARNING

extractions.description: This paper examines the reliability of the Centered Kernel Alignment (CKA) similarity metric in comparing learned neural representations in neural networks. It provides a theoretical analysis of CKA sensitivity to transformations and empirically demonstrates situations where CKA gives counter-intuitive results. The paper also explores methods to manipulate CKA values without significantly altering the functional behavior of neural networks.

type.justification: The paper performs empirical investigations into the reliability of the CKA similarity metric and demonstrates situations where the metric gives unexpected results. Additionally, the paper proposes methods to manipulate CKA values and validates them through experiments.
type.quote: We empirically investigate several weaknesses of the CKA similarity metric, demonstrating situations in which it gives unexpected or counter-intuitive results.

name.justification: The paper focuses on analyzing and comparing neural representations using the CKA similarity metric, which is a core aspect of representation learning.
name.quote: A helpful framework for thinking about these models is that of representation learning, where we view artificial neural networks (ANNs) as learning increasingly complex internal representations as we go deeper through their layers.

name.justification: The paper addresses challenges in comparing representations learned by neural networks, which is a key topic in machine learning.
name.quote: In the last decade, increasingly complex deep learning models have dominated machine learning and have helped us solve, with remarkable accuracy, a multitude of tasks across a wide array of domains.

name.justification: The paper investigates the reliability of CKA, a metric used for understanding representations in deep learning models.
name.quote: Recently, Centered Kernel Alignment (CKA) (Kornblith et al., 2019) was proposed and shown to be able to reliably identify correspondences between representations in architecturally similar networks trained on the same dataset but from different initializations, unlike past methods such as linear regression or CCA based methods.

name.justification: The paper discusses the empirical investigations carried out using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) trained on the CIFAR10 dataset.
name.quote: We consider the 9 layers CNN presented in Sec. 6.1 of Kornblith et al. (2019) trained on CIFAR10.

is_contributed.justification: The CNN model is used but not introduced or contributed by the authors of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We consider the 9 layers CNN presented in Sec. 6.1 of Kornblith et al. (2019) trained on CIFAR10.

is_executed.justification: The CNN model is used in empirical experiments within the paper.
is_executed.quote: We consider the 9 layers CNN presented in Sec. 6.1 of Kornblith et al. (2019) trained on CIFAR10.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper by Krizhevsky et al. (2009) introduces the CIFAR-10 dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In order to analyze this common assumption, we compare the features of: (1) a network trained to generalize on the CIFAR10 image classification task (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), (2) a network trained to 'memorize' the CIFAR10 images (i.e. target labels are random), and (3) an untrained randomly initialized network (for network architecture and training details see the Appendix).

name.justification: The Patch Camelyon dataset is used for testing the generalizability of the CKA metric under different image distributions.
name.quote: In Fig. 10, we use the same networks (trained on CIFAR10) and measure their CKA similarity maps under the Patch Camelyon dataset (Veeling et al., 2018). Patch Camelyon dataset contains histopathologic scans of lymph node sections, which is drastically different from the CIFAR10 dataset both in terms of pixel distribution and the semantics of the data.
